as advanced of a load balancing
configuration that is required within

base with version 1.0 being initially
released in 2001 and it also has a very

of contributors so let's give a little
bit of information on observability
before we dive in so what is
observability according to wikipedia
observability is a measure of how well
internal states of a system can be
inferred from knowledge of its external
outputs Willy taro the author of H a
proxy says that observability helps you
to detect what is not working and why so
when discussing observability our inputs
would be our whole infrastructure and
our outputs would typically be logs in
statistics or our metrics three of the
major pieces involved in observability
would be logging metrics and tracing so
what role can the load bouncer play in
observability while the load balancer is
a great observation point it's typically
centrally located and found at the edge
of the network but in distributed
systems we would have one load balancer
per level of your application
frequently the load balancing decisions
can even depend on various metrics that
are available so let's discuss the
logging and metrics a bit H a proxy has
been known to provide invaluable logging
metrics and its default logs some of the
basic log info that you'll find within
the default HTTP requests log would be
the client IP address the front-end that
was requested the backend and the
destination server that it was sent to
the request method and the request URI
the response status code as well as the
bytes that were transferred in this
particular example we could see that the
front end was Fe main and the back end
was B east or keep and the server that
it was processed to was server 1 we
could see that the request method was a
post and it was sent to an API endpoint
and the response status code was 200
with 814 bytes returned so now that we
have some of the basic log outputs
covered let's discuss some of the
advanced logs a bit H a proxy default
logs also contain various timing
information this allows us to track down
where a slowness happened it allows us
to pinpoint a possible issue the default
timing data you'll find within the H a
proxy logs are how long H a proxy took
waiting for the client to send the full
request this is the time elapsed between
the first bytes received and the moment
H a proxy received the empty line
marking the end of the HTTP headers how
long the request spent waiting in queues
for a connection slot this accounts for
the back end queue as well as the server
queues the total time it took H a proxy
to establish the connect TCP connection
to the server this is essentially the
elapsed time between the moment the
proxy sent the connection request and
the moment it was acknowledged by the
server and we also see how long it took
in total for the server to send the
response this will be the time elapsed
between the moment the TCP connection
was established to the server and the
moment the server sent its complete
response response headers and finally
we'll see the total active time for that
HTTP request between the moment h a
proxy received the first byte of the
real request header and the omission of
the last byte of the response body
another important set of data that is
found within the default logs requests
logs is a two letter code that is the
session state at this connection the
HTTP request logs provide for
characters with the last two characters
indicating whether a cookie was provided
by the client and whether the cookie
operations were performed on the cookie
by the server we won't be covering the
cookie fields in today's presentation so
back to the first two characters the
first character will give us some
information on the first event which
caused the session at terminate the
second character will give us the
session state when it was closed this
helps us to determine which side caused
the end of the session to happen as well
as the reason for the disconnect and
whether it was closed normally or not in
the example here we could see that the
first letter capital C indicates the TCP
session was unexpectedly aborted by the
client and the capital R indicates that
H a proxy was waiting for a complete and
valid request from the client this is
equivalent to a client that will begin
loading a page and then either cancels
the page load or navigates away to
another site H a proxy also provides
various counters within its request logs
which will tell us how many concurrent
connections were being handled within
the process when the session was logged
using this table where a using this data
were able to see how many active
connections there were how many of them
were on the front end in question how
many were on the back end and how many
were on the destination server and and
also how many retries were experienced
by this session when trying to connect
to the backend server so AWS x-ray is a
tool to help analyze and debug
production distributed applications some
of its benefits are it allows you to
review request behavior may traces users
requests as they travel through your
entire application with AWS x-ray you
can gather insights into how your
application is performing and discover
root causes AWS x-ray also helps you
identify performance bottlenecks which
will allow you to improve the overall
performance of your application and
finally it works for both simple and
complex applications and allows you to
analyze a variety of applications so
before we get into everything I'd like

same page
a segment provides the resources name
the details about the request and
details about the work being done and a
segment can break down the data about
the work done in the sub segments sub
segments provide more granular timing
information and details about downstream
calls that your application made to
fulfill the original request and a trace
ID is a unique ID which tracks the path
of a request through your application
annotations are simple key value pairs
that are indexed for use with filter
expressions or search searching on the
data in general and then metadata are
similar to annotations they're also key
value pairs but they can contain values
of any type including objects and lists
but they cannot be searched on or
indexed so a segment a segment at a
minimum requires a name a trace ID a
segment ID and a started in endtime so
